Title: Cortical connections of the frontoparietal opercular areas in the rhesus monkey.
Abstract: The connections of the frontoparietal opercular areas were studied in rhesus monkeys by using antero- and retrograde tracer techniques. The rostral opercular cortex including the gustatory and proisocortical motor (ProM) areas is connected with precentral areas 3, 1, and 2 as well as with the rostral portion of the opercular area which resembles the second somatosensory type of cortex (area SII) and the ventral portion of area 6. Its distant connections are with the ventral portion of prefrontal areas 46, 11, 12, and 13 as well as with the rostral insula and cingulate motor area (CMAr). The mid opercular region (areas 1 and 2) is connected with pre- and postcentral areas 3, 1, and 2 as well as SII. Additionally, it is connected with the ventral portion of area 6, area 44, area ProM, the gustatory area, and the rostral insula. Its distant connections are with area 4, the ventral portion of area 46, area 7b, and area POa in the intraparietal sulcus (IPS). The rostral parietal opercular region is connected with the postcentral portions of areas 3, 1, and 2; areas 5, 7, and SII; the gustatory area; and the vestibular area. Its other connections are with area 4, area 44, the ventral portion of area 46, area ProM, CMAr, and the supplementary motor area (SMA). The caudal opercular region is connected with the dorsal portion of area 3; areas 2, 5, and 7a; and areas PEa as well as IPd of IPS. It is also connected with area SII, insula, and the superior temporal sulcus. Its distant connections are with area 44; the dorsal portion of area 8 and the ventral portion of area 46; as well as CMAr, SMA, and the supplementary sensory area. This connectivity suggests that the ventral somatosensory areas are involved in sensorimotor activities mainly related to head, neck, and face structures as well as to taste. Additionally, these areas may have a role in frontal (working) and temporal (tactile) memory systems.

@BrainMaps.Comments: The authors introduce a concept of a root, belt, and core region among the sensory -and sensorymotorsystem, which are delineated. The other brain sites are unspecifically adopted.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: ""We would like to propose a scheme for the organisation of the ventral somatosensory areas of the sylvian operculum and the postcentral gyrus".."A schematic diagram to illustrate the root, core, and beltöine concept for both the dorsal and ventral somatosensory and motor regions."
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: The authors introduce two root, core, and belt concepts, one for the sensory system only and another one for the whole sensorymotor cortex. Therefore it is neccessary to define two core, root and belt regions, one group named root_s,belt_s, and core_s, concerning the sensory system, another group named root_sm, core_sm, and belt_sm, concerning the whole sensorymotor system.

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Citation: "Architectonic analyses of the insular, opercular, and adjoimimg cortices have been conducted in the macaque monkey by Roberts and Akert(1963). Sanides also parcellated this region in the squirrel monkey. Subsequently, Jones and Burton (1976) described the boundaries of this regions in both species.."
@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Comments: The authors are adopting brain sites through parts of the whole article, whereas it is not usefull to cite every entry.

publication.title: Cortical connections of the frontoparietal opercular areas in the rhesus monkey.
publication.abstract: The connections of the frontoparietal opercular areas were studied in rhesus monkeys by using antero- and retrograde tracer techniques. The rostral opercular cortex including the gustatory and proisocortical motor (ProM) areas is connected with precentral areas 3, 1, and 2 as well as with the rostral portion of the opercular area which resembles the second somatosensory type of cortex (area SII) and the ventral portion of area 6. Its distant connections are with the ventral portion of prefrontal areas 46, 11, 12, and 13 as well as with the rostral insula and cingulate motor area (CMAr). The mid opercular region (areas 1 and 2) is connected with pre- and postcentral areas 3, 1, and 2 as well as SII. Additionally, it is connected with the ventral portion of area 6, area 44, area ProM, the gustatory area, and the rostral insula. Its distant connections are with area 4, the ventral portion of area 46, area 7b, and area POa in the intraparietal sulcus (IPS). The rostral parietal opercular region is connected with the postcentral portions of areas 3, 1, and 2; areas 5, 7, and SII; the gustatory area; and the vestibular area. Its other connections are with area 4, area 44, the ventral portion of area 46, area ProM, CMAr, and the supplementary motor area (SMA). The caudal opercular region is connected with the dorsal portion of area 3; areas 2, 5, and 7a; and areas PEa as well as IPd of IPS. It is also connected with area SII, insula, and the superior temporal sulcus. Its distant connections are with area 44; the dorsal portion of area 8 and the ventral portion of area 46; as well as CMAr, SMA, and the supplementary sensory area. This connectivity suggests that the ventral somatosensory areas are involved in sensorimotor activities mainly related to head, neck, and face structures as well as to taste. Additionally, these areas may have a role in frontal (working) and temporal (tactile) memory systems.
